On F=
ri, 26 Oct 2007 07:47:45 -0800, Moffat, Harry K <hkmoffa@...>  
wrot=
e:

> Hi,
>    I've updated the setState_HP(), setState_UV(), setState_SP()=
, and
> setState_SV() routines in the CVS version of Cantera to use a root
=
> finder algorithm rather than a Newton's method. There's a new test
> prob=
lem, CpJump, that demonstrates that the new  algorithm can handle
> jumps i=
n Cp and H at temperature boundaries. The old algorithm could not
> handle =
these jumps. I hope this helps your application.
>
> Best wishes,
> Harry M=
offat
>
>
> Harry Moffat                                             (w) (5=
05)
> 844-6912
> Multiphase & Nanoscale Transport Division    (f)   (505) 8=
44-8251
> Sandia National Laboratories
> hkmoffa@...
> P. O. Box 580=
0-0836
> Albuquerque, NM 87185-0836
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: =
cantera@yahoogroups.com [mailto:cantera@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf
> Of Mof=
fat, Harry K
> Sent: Wednesday, October 24, 2007 3:09 PM
> To: cantera@yaho=
ogroups.com
> Subject: RE: [cantera] CANTERA Roulette!! Error: no convergen=
ce. dt =3D
> 0.000219057
>
> Hi,
>    Since the entropy and enthalpy are mo=
notonic functions of T, I could
> probably change the solution algorithm to=
 a root finder algorithm rather
> than the Newton's method that is currentl=
y being employed. Newton's
> method rigorously requires that the first deri=
vative be continuous for
> convergence to be achieved. This in turn require=
s that Cp and H and/or S
> be continuous at temperature boundaries. This is=
 normally the case, and
> a warning message is printed out if it isn't the =
case. However, the
> question then becomes to what degree are these functio=
ns continuous
> across temperature boundaries and can one then make a state=
ment about
> how "continuous" they have to be in order for the setState_HP =
and
> setState_SP functions to converge for all cases.
>    A root finder a=
lgorithm has less requirements on the smoothness of
> the function than a N=
ewton's method algorithm. So, it should be more
> robust.
>
>    Also, I co=
uld expose the convergence requirements for these two
> functions in the ma=
tlab levels. Currently, they are exposed at the C++
> level with defaults o=
n dT of 1.0E-4.
>
> Best wishes,
> Harry Moffat
>
>
>
> Harry Moffat       =
                                      (w) (505)
> 844-6912
> Multiphase & N=
anoscale Transport Division    (f)   (505) 844-8251
> Sandia National Labor=
atories
> hkmoffa@...
> P. O. Box 5800-0836
> Albuquerque, NM 87185-=
0836

:cantera@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf
> Of Winston Burbank

 October 17, 2007 11:46 PM

ubject: [cantera] CANTERA Roulette!! Error: no convergence. dt =3D
> 0.0002=
19057
>
> Procedure: setState_SP
> Error:   no convergence. dt =3D 0.000219=
057
>
> I feel like my research has become a game of roulette!  I am using
=
> Cantera  from within Matlab, where I solve systems of compressors and
> t=
urbines.  It works great most of the time!  However when my code asks
> Can=
tera to setState_SP (entropy and Pressure) or set_State_HP and this
> state=
 fall sufficiently close to 1000K, Cantera crashes.  I know I could
> fudge=
 my quarry in the hopes I don't land on a 1000K condition but I
> would rat=
her know my code (and Cantera) are rock stable.
>
> I believe this is happe=
ning because of the NASA polynomials switching
> coefficients at 1000K, and=
 while the polynomials are close to each
> other, the setState function req=
uires 10^-8 accuracy (way more than I
> require).
>
> I am hoping someone e=
lse has solved this problem or can offer
> assistance.
> My current thought=
 is to find the function(s) where the polynomial
> coefficients are chosen =
for the appropriate temperature range.   Then
> add
> a case such that betw=
een T =3D 999 and 1001 a new polynomial will be
> interpolated and used for=
 the subsequent thermo calculations.
> Unfortunately I have yet to find whi=
ch functions these are and deduce if
> this may really work/help?
>
> Your =
help will be greatly appreciated,
> Winston Burbank
> ftwsb@...
